G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Superior Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy, including medical expenses, lost wages, and general damages for pain and suffering, exceeds $25,000 when fully and fairly valued.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the events and injuries giving rise to this action occurred in Pittsfield, Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and the Property that is the subject of this action is situated in Berkshire County.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to the property, and to persons foreseeably using adjacent public ways, to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the probable seriousness of such injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708–09 (1973); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to the property, and to persons foreseeably using adjacent public ways, to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the probable seriousness of such injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708–09 (1973); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.support_reasoning: Mounsey is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, evaluated in light of circumstances such as likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk. The quoted concurring passage does not itself articulate that standard, but elsewhere in the opinion (at 708–09) the court adopts a unified reasonable-care duty to lawful entrants. The case does not primarily concern persons on adjacent public ways, but it does support the duty-to-all-lawful-visitors component of the proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708\u2.relevant_excerpt: We hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees should be abolished. Henceforth, a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. In determining whether the landowner has exercised reasonable care in the maintenance of his property, the factors to be considered include the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk. The status of the visitor is no longer determinative, but is only one circumstance to be weighed in assessing the reasonableness of the landowner’s conduct.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes a duty to all lawful visitors to the property, and to persons foreseeably using adjacent public ways, to exercise reasonable care to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury, the probable seriousness of such injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk. See G.L. c. 231, § 85; Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 708–09 (1973); Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739, 743–44 (1995).
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly restates Massachusetts premises-liability law that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors, including the duty to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of unreasonable dangers. It also acknowledges a duty to exercise reasonable care in the use of land so as not to injure travelers on adjacent highways. Although the holding ultimately limits any duty to alter a state highway, the general duty rule quoted in the proposition is directly supported by the court’s discussion citing Mounsey and related cases.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.”

Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 39.raw_text: Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 395 Mass. 581, 583–84 (1985)
Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 39.proposition: This duty of reasonable care extends to the maintenance of trees and structures on private property that may foreseeably fall or shed limbs onto neighboring property or public ways and cause injury. See Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 395 Mass. 581, 583–84 (1985) (duty regarding tree limbs overhanging adjacent property); Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372, 378–79 (1980) (duty to anticipate reasonably foreseeable consequences of conditions adjacent to public ways).
Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 39.case_name: Ferragamo v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 39.support_reasoning: Ferragamo is a products-liability / UCC merchantability and warning case about toxic PVC in a sold trolley car, not a premises-liability case about trees or structures on land falling onto neighboring property or public ways. The opinion nowhere discusses duties arising from ownership or control of land, overhanging limbs, or structures adjacent to public ways. Citing Ferragamo for a duty regarding tree limbs overhanging adjacent property mischaracterizes its subject matter and holding.
Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 39.relevant_excerpt: “The judge further held that although ‘[t]he evidence on this question is slight,’ there was ‘enough to warrant a jury to find that PVC was present on or in the car; that this presence was known or should have been known to the defendant and imposed on the defendant a duty to warn of the danger involved in cutting up the car with an acetylene torch.’”

Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..raw_text: Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372, 378–79 (1980)
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..proposition: This duty of reasonable care extends to the maintenance of trees and structures on private property that may foreseeably fall or shed limbs onto neighboring property or public ways and cause injury. See Ferragamo v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 395 Mass. 581, 583–84 (1985) (duty regarding tree limbs overhanging adjacent property); Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass. 372, 378–79 (1980) (duty to anticipate reasonably foreseeable consequences of conditions adjacent to public ways).
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..support_reasoning: Bernier does not involve trees or private land, but it clearly articulates a duty to design and maintain structures (here, an electric light pole) in a manner reasonably accommodated to foreseeable vehicle impacts so as to avoid injury to people lawfully using public streets and sidewalks. The court emphasizes that Edison must anticipate the environment adjacent to public ways and design against reasonably foreseeable risks to pedestrians. Thus, while the facts concern pole design rather than trees, the case supports the broader proposition that a duty of reasonable care extends to conditions on land or structures adjacent to public ways that may foreseeably cause injury.
Bernier v. Boston Edison Co., 380 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “As designer or codesigner of the pole and in control of its maintenance, Edison ‘must anticipate the environment in which its product will be used, and it must design against the reasonably foreseeable risks attending the product’s use in that setting.’… As in the case of vehicles, design should take into account ‘foreseeable participation in collisions’… This was a busy shopping area with heavy pedestrian and vehicular traffics… [T]he jury could rationally find negligence of design and maintenance… creating an unacceptable risk of grave injury to persons at the scene.”

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that an owner or person in control of land must act as a reasonable person in maintaining property in a safe condition, including remedying or warning about hazards of which the owner knows or should know through the exercise of reasonable care. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 371–72 (2010); O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204–05 (2000).
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, property owners owe lawful visitors a duty to act as a reasonable person in maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition. In abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation rule, the court makes clear that this reasonable care duty applies equally to hazards from snow and ice and includes taking reasonable steps to protect visitors from known or reasonably knowable dangers. That is materially consistent with the proposition stated.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that an owner or person in control of land must act as a reasonable person in maintaining property in a safe condition, including remedying or warning about hazards of which the owner knows or should know through the exercise of reasonable care. See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368, 371–72 (2010); O’Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204–05 (2000).
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the general Massachusetts rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to lawful visitors, including maintaining the property in a reasonably safe condition and warning of unreasonable dangers the owner knows or should know about. Although the case ultimately finds no duty to warn because the hazard was open and obvious, its articulation of the baseline premises-liability duty aligns directly with the proposition cited.
O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201,.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to ‘maintain[ ] his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk,’ … and ‘to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.’” (431 Mass. at 204).

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007)
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: A property owner is liable for harm caused by a defective condition on the property where the owner knew or reasonably should have known of the condition and unreasonably failed to correct it or to warn others. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007); Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 as the governing standard for premises liability, which provides that a possessor of land is liable for physical harm caused by a condition on the land if the possessor knows or should know of the condition and fails to exercise reasonable care to protect invitees. Although Sheehan modifies how notice can be proved in self‑service settings (mode of operation), it reaffirms that liability is premised on knowledge—actual or constructive—plus an unreasonable failure to protect or warn. That is materially consistent with the proposition stated.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: “Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: ‘A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees, and (b) should expect that they will not discover or realize the danger, or will fail to protect themselves against it, and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.’”

Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.raw_text: Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973)
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.proposition: A property owner is liable for harm caused by a defective condition on the property where the owner knew or reasonably should have known of the condition and unreasonably failed to correct it or to warn others. See Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780, 784–85 (2007); Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165, 167–68 (1973).
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep them reasonably safe or to warn of dangers the owner knows or ought to know about. That is the same negligence standard embodied in the proposition (knowledge—actual or constructive—plus unreasonable failure to remedy or warn). Oliveri then applies this standard to foreign substances on stairs, analyzing whether the defendant should have discovered and removed the condition, which directly aligns with the cited rule.
Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … [T]he plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent the Tree and its branches from constituting a dangerous condition to individuals lawfully using the adjacent public sidewalk, and to warn of or correct any such dangerous conditions upon actual or constructive notice. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 198–200 (1994); Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987).
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.support_reasoning: The case concerns a commercial landlord’s duty to protect lawful occupants from criminal attacks in interior common areas, not a landowner’s duty regarding trees or dangerous conditions affecting adjacent public sidewalks. While the opinion articulates a general duty of commercial landowners to take reasonable precautions against reasonably foreseeable risks in common areas, it does not address maintenance of trees, adjacent sidewalks, or duties to warn or correct such outdoor hazardous conditions. Thus, citing Whittaker for the specific sidewalk/tree-duty proposition is inaccurate.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 360 (1965)… The question in this appeal is whether the evidence warranted a finding that an attack on the plaintiff was reasonably foreseeable.”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Defendant further owed Plaintiff a duty to take reasonable steps to prevent the Tree and its branches from constituting a dangerous condition to individuals lawfully using the adjacent public sidewalk, and to warn of or correct any such dangerous conditions upon actual or constructive notice. See Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 198–200 (1994); Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837, 842 (1987).
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted passage from Young v. Atlantic Richfield concerns whether a gasoline station owed a duty to warn customers of the obvious risk of negligent operation of other vehicles at a self-service station. It does not address a landowner’s duty regarding trees or branches creating a dangerous condition on an adjacent public sidewalk, nor duties to inspect, maintain, or warn with respect to such conditions. The case therefore does not support the specific sidewalk/tree-duty proposition for which it is cited.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.raw_text: Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.proposition: Independently of actual notice, Defendant had constructive notice of the hazardous condition, because the defective nature of the Hazardous Branch existed for a sufficient period of time and was sufficiently apparent that a reasonably prudent property owner, in the exercise of ordinary care, would have discovered the condition through reasonable inspection. See Sheehan, 448 Mass. at 785–86; Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961).
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states the constructive-notice rule in slip-and-fall cases: when the defendant did not cause the condition and lacks actual notice, the plaintiff must prove the hazard existed long enough that, in the exercise of reasonable care, the defendant should have discovered and remedied or warned of it. The court then holds against the plaintiff only because there was insufficient evidence of the duration or discoverability of the oil, but the legal standard matches the proposition cited from Deagle.
Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co., 343.relevant_excerpt: “There was no evidence, however, that the dangerous condition was caused by a person for whose conduct the defendant was responsible or that the defendant’s employees knew of the condition. In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence and taken steps to remove it or to warn the customers.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.proposition: Having actual and/or constructive notice of the hazardous condition, Defendant was obligated to take reasonable steps to remedy the danger or otherwise protect foreseeable pedestrians, including Plaintiff, from harm. See Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013); Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc., 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461, 463–64 (1998).
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses a landowner’s duty when it has created and maintained a dangerous condition and knows lawful entrants will encounter it. The SJC holds that even where the danger is open and obvious, the landowner is not relieved of the duty to remedy that danger if it can and should anticipate harm, which necessarily includes taking reasonable steps to protect foreseeable entrants from that hazard. This aligns with the proposition that, upon actual or constructive notice of a hazardous condition, a defendant must take reasonable steps to remedy or otherwise protect foreseeable pedestrians (or entrants) from harm.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner, though, ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ Papadopoulos, supra, quoting Soederberg… Section 343A thus instructs that… a landowner is not relieved from remedying that danger where he knows or has reason to know that lawful entrants may not heed the warning…. On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”}

Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.raw_text: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc., 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461, 463–64 (1998)
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.proposition: Having actual and/or constructive notice of the hazardous condition, Defendant was obligated to take reasonable steps to remedy the danger or otherwise protect foreseeable pedestrians, including Plaintiff, from harm. See Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 154–55 (2013); Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc., 45 Mass. App. Ct. 461, 463–64 (1998).
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.case_name: Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.support_reasoning: This decision is a Chapter 21E contaminated-property damages case about the proper measure of cleanup and diminution-in-value damages and related attorney’s fees. It does not address premises liability, duties to pedestrians, or any rule that a defendant with actual or constructive notice of a hazardous condition must take reasonable steps to remedy or protect foreseeable pedestrians. Citing this case for that general negligence/premises duty proposition misstates its holding and context.
Black v. Coastal Oil New England, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “Because § 5 is silent as to how to measure the damages for the private right of action created by it, we look to the common law for guidance. At common law, the measure of damages to real property is dependent upon whether ‘the injury is permanent’ or ‘reasonably curable by repairs.’ … When the injury is temporary… the expense of repairs, if less than the diminished market value, is the measure of recovery. … As we have indicated, to the extent that the expense of cleanup was recoverable at the time of this action, that recovery could be pursued only under § 4.”

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: Reasonable care requires landowners to anticipate and guard against the effects of ordinary foreseeable weather conditions on known defective structures or trees. See Bernier, 380 Mass. at 378–79; Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105–06 (1978).
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: Jesionek concerns a landowner’s duty to secure a dangerous forklift against foreseeable misuse by intoxicated seamen and resulting injury to invitees. The opinion does discuss foreseeability and the need to guard against third‑party misuse of a dangerous instrumentality, but it does not address weather, defective structures, or trees, nor any duty specific to ordinary foreseeable weather conditions. Thus, citing Jesionek for a proposition about reasonable care regarding weather effects on defective structures or trees is not accurate authority.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard C.raw_text: Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 12 Mass. App. Ct. 431, 434–35 (1981)
Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard C.proposition: To the extent Defendant may assert that the falling branch was solely the result of an “act of God,” such a defense is inapplicable where the defendant’s negligence has combined with foreseeable natural forces to produce the harm. See, e.g., Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard Coll., 12 Mass. App. Ct. 431, 434–35 (1981) (landowner liability where natural conditions interact with negligent maintenance).
Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard C.support_reasoning: The opinion is a conflicts/constructive trust case involving family members and land, not a tort or premises-liability case involving an ‘act of God’ or natural forces causing physical harm. It does not discuss negligent maintenance, falling branches, or the interaction of negligence with natural conditions; instead it analyzes which state’s law governs constructive trusts and fiduciary relationships. The proposition about inapplicability of an ‘act of God’ defense when negligence combines with natural forces is therefore not supported by this case.
Rugo v. President & Fellows of Harvard C.relevant_excerpt: The most important interest of the situs in land transactions is the protection of bona fide purchasers or other persons who rely on the record title. Additionally, it is desirable for purposes of convenience that a purchaser and his title searchers need consult only the law of one jurisdiction. . . . Here there are no such persons involved as these proceedings are solely between the defendant, the record holder of the real estate, and the plaintiff.

Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.raw_text: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 336–38 (2010)
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.proposition: Any contention that the danger was “open and obvious” does not bar Plaintiff’s recovery because: a. The precise risk of sudden limb failure under the prevailing weather conditions was not obvious to an ordinary pedestrian; and b. Even where a danger is open and obvious, a landowner may remain liable when it is foreseeable that lawful visitors will nonetheless encounter the hazard in the course of their ordinary use of the premises and there are reasonable steps that the landowner could and should take to prevent harm. See Dos Santos, 465 Mass. at 154–56; Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass’n, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 333, 336–38 (2010).
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.case_name: Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condominium Association
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the open and obvious nature of an ice hazard does not negate a landowner’s duty to remedy it, and that a plaintiff’s decision to confront such a hazard goes to comparative negligence rather than a complete bar to recovery. The court further relies on Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343A comment f, explicitly recognizing that landowners may remain liable for open and obvious dangers where it is foreseeable that invitees will still encounter them and the owner can and should anticipate resulting harm. This aligns with the proposition that open and obvious conditions do not bar recovery, especially where it is foreseeable that lawful visitors will proceed and reasonable remedial steps exist.
Soederberg v. Concord Greene Condo. Ass\.relevant_excerpt: “No reported Massachusetts case has held that the obviousness of the dangers posed by the hazards of an unnatural accumulation of snow or ice negates an owner’s duty to remedy the hazard. … The Restatement recognizes that a property owner or possessor should not be relieved from remedying open and obvious dangers where he ‘can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the invitee notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.’ … [I]t is entirely foreseeable that people will engage snow or ice hazards lying in well-traveled pathways, even if those hazards are open and obvious.”

Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.proposition: To the extent any negligence might be attributed to Plaintiff, Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was less than the negligence of Defendant, and Plaintiff’s claim is therefore not barred under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85. See Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 50, 62–63 (1988).
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses how Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, operates in a negligence action, and holds that a plaintiff’s conduct only bars recovery if his negligence exceeds that of the defendant(s). The court explains that even where the plaintiff’s conduct was found to bar recovery on a warranty theory (unreasonable use), that finding does not bar his negligence claim; instead, under § 85, the trier of fact must compare the plaintiff’s negligence with that of the defendants and bar recovery only if the plaintiff’s share is greater than 50%. This directly supports the proposition that a plaintiff whose negligence is less than the defendant’s is not barred from recovery under § 85.
Colter v. Barber-Greene Co., 403 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.). … The plaintiff's conduct … does not bar recovery completely unless the plaintiff is more than fifty per cent responsible for his or her own injuries.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 60F, 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and other general damages. See, e.g., G.L. c. 231, §§ 60F, 85; doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 787–88 (1975).

doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover fair and reasonable compensation for all past and future damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical expenses, lost earnings, pain and suffering, and other general damages. See, e.g., G.L. c. 231, §§ 60F, 85; doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776, 787–88 (1975).
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the components of the plaintiff’s damages award and approves a substantial jury verdict, listing the elements the jury could consider: lost earning capacity, pain and suffering, disfigurement, future medical needs (artificial hands), and ongoing discomfort. In affirming denial of a new trial for excessiveness, the SJC recognizes that such past and future items of loss are proper elements of compensatory damages in a Massachusetts personal injury action. That aligns with the proposition that a plaintiff may recover fair and reasonable compensation for all such damages proximately caused by the defendant’s negligence.
doCanto v. Ametek, Inc., 367 Mass. 776,.relevant_excerpt: “In concluding that the judge committed no error of law, we consider Ezila’s age (twenty-nine) and weekly earnings ($140) at the time of the accident; the loss of ninety-five per cent of the function of her right hand (her dominant hand); her inability to perform many household tasks or to obtain employment; her pain and suffering, particularly while her hand was in the machine and while she was in the hospital…; her disfigurement…; her future need for artificial hands; and her continuing discomfort and embarrassment.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment and post-judgment interest on all damages awarded, as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7\u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Costs of this action, including filing fees and other allowable court costs, pursuant to G.L. c. 261, §§ 1 et seq.
